Issues.Title: Ternary operator misinterpretation in v-model attribute
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.5.16

### Reproduction link
[https://jsfiddle.net/zmkt7ajy/178/](https://jsfiddle.net/zmkt7ajy/178/)

### Steps to reproduce
You can see how the ternary operator only evaluates to the 
"false" value for the v-model attribute, rendering the checkboxes 
"unwired" to the models in the "true" cases. 
Evaluating elsewhere, in a different attribute or inline 
(see checkbox labels and bottom `<span>` iteration) 
proves it's only an issue with the v-model's parser. 

### What is expected?
all checkboxes represent a model.

### What is actually happening?
"true" evaluations return no model entity. 

---
I have managed to insert a console logging for what the "true" evaluation returns, 
and it is as if the ternary operands were an object key-value pair. 
for example: 
`v-model="typeof item==='string'?model.strings:model.numbers" `
returns something like  `{model.strings:{numbers:[]}}` in case of "string" types.

also, in a previous stage of my actual code I could bypass this issue 
by varying the boolean expression (like checking for existence 
of property instead of type verification but after a heavy restructuring 
I can't reproduce it already. I went with separating the cases with v-if this time, but whatever). 
In a certain case then, the "true" operands were returned and referenced correctly. 

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Ternary operator misinterpretation in v-model attribute" (#8390)

Issues.Title: Bound data value does not update as expected
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.5.16

### Reproduction link
[https://codepen.io/experiencehq/pen/yEKMwv](https://codepen.io/experiencehq/pen/yEKMwv)

### Steps to reproduce
1. Create a new component, which expects a single property (in the example, `color`)
2. Create a `data` property, based on the bound property (`data-color`)
3. Create a `computed` property, based on the bound property (`computed-color`)
4. Note that the `data-color` and `computed-color` values are correct when the component is first loaded
5. Update the bound property value
6. Note that the `computed-color` value updates as expected, but **the `data-color` value does not update**

### What is expected?
The `data-color` value should change when the bound property upon which it is based changes, [as described in the documentation](https://vuejs.org/v2/guide/components-props.html):

> ...every time the parent component is updated, all props in the child component will be refreshed with the latest value.

### What is actually happening?
The `data-color` value does not change.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Bound data value does not update as expected" (#8387)

Issues.Title: Add a "jsFilter" option to the context object used by the server renderer
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
This option would allow a user to override the filter that determines what JS files get automatically injected into the generated HTML. Presently, I think this can be achieved by Manual Asset Injection (https://ssr.vuejs.org/guide/build-config.html#client-config) but if the only thing a user wants to control is which bundle gets injected in a multi-compiler Webpack setup, then this creates A LOT of extra work for them as they try to duplicate all the things that vue-server-renderer would do for them by default.

My specific use case is that I'm generating a JS bundle for each language that we want our application to support using i18n-webpack-plugin. When using vue-server-renderer, the last language bundle generated is automatically injected. This feature would allow me to instead add logic to `createContext` that looks at a request's locale header, generates a filter function based on that header, and uses that filter function to assure that a matching (or a default) bundle is injected in the returned page.

### What does the proposed API look like?
Adding this variable to the `renderScripts` method:
```js
const jsFilter = context.jsFilter || (({ file }) => isJS(file))
```
And passing `jsFilter` to the filter calls in that method instead of the default, `({ file }) => isJS(file)`.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Add a "jsFilter" option to the context object used by the server renderer" (#8378)

Issues.Title: Dynamic input field type renders invalid code in IE11
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.5.17-beta.0

### Reproduction link
[https://github.com/nirazul/vue-loader-bug-repro](https://github.com/nirazul/vue-loader-bug-repro)

### Steps to reproduce
1. `npm install`
2. `npm run build`
3. `npm run watch`
4. Open `./public/index.html`
5. Inspect `main.bundle.js` in dev tools
6. On line 9044 you will find a duplicated key `value`

### What is expected?
A valid output from vue-template-compiler without duplicated value props, or at least a warning that the usage of dynamic input field types is prohibited in certain cases.

### What is actually happening?
In IE11 a blank page is rendered

---
I'm using a centralized component for both radio and checkbox input fields as the markup is 90% the same.
As we switched from webpack 3 to webpack 4, we had to also upgrade the vue-loader version from 12 to 13 or 14, which introduced this bug. 
Prior to version 13, vue-template-renderer was not enforcing strict mode on all of its rendered templates. This is now the case, introducing this critical bug.


References:
https://vuejs.org/v2/guide/forms.html#Radio-1
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/issues/7048
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/issues/6917

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

Issues.Title: v-for documentation conflicts with warnings
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.5.13

### Reproduction link
[https://jsfiddle.net/1dncegky/](https://jsfiddle.net/1dncegky/)

### Steps to reproduce
Intentionally include a v-for with no key per documentation

### What is expected?
No warning is shown

### What is actually happening?
A warning is shown indicating that it was a mistake to not include a key

---
The problem is actually in the documentation. In https://vuejs.org/v2/guide/list.html#key the documentation indicates that sometimes not including a key is fine, but there will be a build warning if you don't include the key at all. It appears that the system will be fine with a key of "undefined". It clarifies that it was considered that we would include a key and intentional that it was not included. The code seems to work as expected, the warning is suppressed, everyone's happy.

My request is that the docs get updated and the warning gets updated to clue people in to that as a solution to the warning when you really don't want to include a separate key.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "v-for documentation conflicts with warnings" (#8372)

Issues.Title: Replace boolean params with string placeholders
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
Imagine a route path like this: 
`{ path: '/thanks/:polite/:foo?', component: Thanks } `
...with one or more boolean parameters.

The URL would look like this `/thanks/true/true`

it would be nice to be able to substitute the "true" state by a string-placeholder, so the URL would look like this:
`/thanks/polite/foo` or `/thanks/polite` (or even `/thanks/foo/` if "polite" is false)

### What does the proposed API look like?
Syntax could be:
`{ path: '/thanks/:!polite/:!foo?', component: Thanks } `
... if a parameter name starts with "`!`" it is considered to be a boolean value, and its name will be the substitution of the true value or it will be left out if false.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Replace boolean params with string placeholders" (#2261)

Issues.Title: Allow a user to read and write state on history entries
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?

Mobile apps that want to save scroll position for elements besides window.

This would also allow the user to save whatever they want to history state. A project I'm working on now needs to keep track of what's "focused" per page and this seems like the correct place for it. It could also be a nice place for temporary form data. I'm sure there's a lot of use cases outside of this.


### What does the proposed API look like?

I'm still thinking about it, though I think someone else thinking about it would be better. :)

I checked out `react-router` a bit and it looks like we can make state part of the Location object, so we can set it in `$router.push|replace({...})` or `next({...})` calls. They use an additional argument but we might not need to?

I took a quick look at react-router and it seems to allow for this: https://github.com/ReactTraining/react-router/blob/master/packages/react-router/docs/api/history.md

Also, this seems to talk directly to the situation we're facing with scrolling:
https://reacttraining.com/react-router/web/guides/scroll-restoration

Also some additional reading: https://github.com/ReactTraining/history#properties

Hopefully this is useful and doesn't seem like useless rambling.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

Issues.Title: Dynamic modules that use Namespaces need a way to check if they are already registered
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
When registering a dynamic module, an error can occur in the console warning that some attributes of the modules are duplicates if the namespace has already been registered. Having a way to check if the namespace path is already occupied would allow the code to either, register to a different namespace (ick!), unregister and re-register the existing namespace or avoid registration of the namespace altogether. 

This condition can be easily reproduced by dynamically registering a namespaced module and issuing a hotreload or attempting to register that module more than once to the same path. 

End users would not see errors on hot-load or, if for some reason, the code attempts multiple registrations in the same session.

The only workaround at this point is to check the private member _modulesNamespaceMap. Building a dependency on that private access isn't ideal. I can find no other way to determine if the namespace is already occupied. 

### What does the proposed API look like?
Option A: Provide a boolean method that returns the state of a given namespace:

    this.$store.isNamespaceRegistered("nested/name/space")

Option B: Exit from registerModule and provide a false return code from registerModule when the namespace already exists. 

    if (this.$store.registerModule("existing/namespace", myModule) === false) {
       this.$store.unregisterModule("existing/namespace")
       this.$store.registerModule("existing/namespace", myModule)
    }

I personally like Option A better as it is minimally intrusive on the existing API and gives the developer the means by which to handle the issue with the greatest flexibility.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Dynamic modules that use Namespaces need a way to check if they are already registered" (#1300)

Issues.Title: store.registerGetters and store.registerActions
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
To be able to fully code split all application logic across application routes it would be helpful to have a way to dynamically register getters and actions.  Currently registerModule only supports registering namespaced modules with `store.registerModule`.  

For example lets say you have two namespaced modules that you dynamically load into your application: Sandwich and Human.  The two modules shouldn't know anything about each other.  There needs to be some highter level actions and getters that can tie the two together that you can also dynamically load.

### What does the proposed API look like?
```
store.registerActions({
  ...newActions
})

store.registerGetters({
  ...newGetters
})
```
These functions would still throw errors if the user tried to register duplicate actions or getters so it would be up the the user to make sure they are not passing in duplicates by checking existing data and making sure their actions and getters are namespaced appropriately.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "store.registerGetters and store.registerActions" (#1299)

Issues.Title: Option to namespace a module but not have it localized
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
The `namespaced:true` module feature has two main purposes: 

1. it automatically namespaces your modules API ( e.g store.getters['namespace/myGetter']). 
2. it localizes dispatch, commit, getters, and state. 

I'd like is to have an option when defining a module that does 1. but does not do 2. as mentioned above. I understand that there are currently two ways to achieve what I want in user land but neither of them are ideal.

1. Define modules that are `namespaced` that have actions and getters that only reference rootGetters, rootState and dispatch to root. I've never like using the root features. Seems like it throws encapsulation out of the door.
2. Define modules that are not `namespaced` and manually namespace modules yourself. This is currently what I'm doing.

### What does the proposed API look like?

String `namespace` - Setting `namespace` would namespace all actions, getters, and mutations with that value. A "." separator to be able to distinguish between a namespaced module that is localized ("/") and not localized ("."). A module with this setting should never have state as it's only purpose is to group together other modules actions, getters, and mutations to do higher order operations.

Some validations worth calling out.
- if the namespace option was set, validate that there is no state defined.
